channel.title: 纽约时报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: One of the easiest ways to upgrade your mask protection is to wear two at the same time, health experts say. Here are answers to common questions about double masking. https://t.co/lF3GyEKs65

We are making public hundreds of the Pentagon’s confidential assessments of reports of civilian casualties resulting from airstrikes. The documents lay bare how flawed intelligence has killed thousands of innocent civilians, many of them children. https://t.co/D1vE9aEDYh

Breaking News: “Saturday Night Live” announced, just hours before its final show of 2021, that there would be no live audience “out of an abundance of caution” amid the surge of coronavirus cases in New York tied to the Omicron variant. https://t.co/SDtfMN3GF5

President Biden saw more of his judicial nominees confirmed in his first year than any president in the last 40 years. The Senate confirmed 18 federal judges in Donald Trump’s first year. https://t.co/IWfPQouWJN
Breaking News: The Netherlands ordered a full lockdown until mid-January in Europe's strongest reaction to the Omicron variant so far. https://t.co/uSsO32fS50

A 5-year New York Times investigation into hidden Pentagon records shows that a pattern of failures in U.S. airstrikes in the Middle East has killed thousands of civilians, many of them children. None of these records show findings of wrongdoing. https://t.co/6VCYUtSZXf

A growing number of Black elected officials across the U.S. have been drawn out of their districts or placed in newly competitive districts. Almost all of the affected lawmakers are Democrats, and most of the mapmakers are white Republicans. https://t.co/YvbSS8nhLu

"Unvaccinated Americans — who are disproportionately Republican — are now in even more danger than a few weeks ago," @DLeonhardt writes in The Morning newsletter. He says a clear message from conservative pundits, many of whom are vaccinated, could help. https://t.co/jKaEECAaah

Neal Moore, 50, crossed the U.S. by canoe “to see the country up close and personal.”
He began in the Columbia River in Oregon, crossed several northern states and traveled to the Gulf Coast. After 22 months, he paddled into New York Harbor this week. https://t.co/AxmkzfMMRZ

France announced plans to tighten restrictions on the unvaccinated in the new year. If the new law is approved, only vaccinated people will be eligible for a French health pass, which is required to be in public spaces like restaurants, museums and trains. https://t.co/o5OVjtw8wR

Elijah Wood kept a pair of hairy hobbit feet in the same box they were given to him in for over 20 years, reminding him of his time in "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy. As he reflects on his career, he knows that to some fans, he will always be Frodo. https://t.co/jHL67WGB13
Masks work best when everyone in the room has one on, but you’ll still benefit from masking up even when those around you aren’t. Here's what the evidence shows. https://t.co/ILuj0LdBJq
Breaking News: A federal appeals court reinstated a Biden administration rule requiring that many large companies mandate vaccines or weekly Covid testing. https://t.co/ems4j9o9Dv
Breaking News: New York State officials reported 21,027 new coronavirus cases on Friday, the highest in a single day since testing became widespread. https://t.co/ODckaoWbfU

One of the easiest ways to upgrade your mask protection is to wear two at the same time, health experts say. Here are answers to common questions about double masking. https://t.co/Qp4OycZG16 https://t.co/R2dSYu6oMP

The CEO of Southwest Airlines, Gary Kelly, tested positive for the coronavirus after appearing at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, the company said. Kelly tested negative several times before the hearing and is fully vaccinated with a booster shot. https://t.co/YnAsPKWKOH

Without a basement, Clara Lutz of Barnsley, Kentucky, sheltered her infant grandsons in the bathtub for safety. A powerful tornado pulled the tub from her grip and sent the babies flying. https://t.co/tUn8nJU4ib https://t.co/q5OHAnxVlr

Breaking News: A Florida man who threw a fire extinguisher at the police on Jan. 6 was sentenced to more than five years in prison, the longest sentence handed to any of the more than 700 people charged in the Capitol attack so far. https://t.co/bMciNvXhZP

Fires in California, hurricanes on the East Coast, a deadly snowstorm in Texas, tornadoes in the Southern U.S. and melting ice in Canada.
Look back at some of the destruction brought about by climate change in 2021 through our #YearInPictures. https://t.co/yTKWUvYXuH
Breaking News: Pfizer said its two-shot vaccine didn’t perform adequately in children 2 to 5, and it will test a three-dose series for official authorization. https://t.co/G8NhvNAhz8

One of them plunged into a burning truck to save others. One made a shield with his body to allow an evacuating helicopter to fly away. One ran toward a breach in the wall of his base to stop an insurgent attack.
They were all awarded medals of honor. https://t.co/sieyJAyOqa
A federal judge overturned Purdue Pharma’s opioid settlement, ruling that the Sackler family could not receive protection from civil lawsuits. https://t.co/TsCoM8ys0o

At least a dozen restaurants and bars in New York City temporarily closed this week as workers test positive for Covid. The reported number of new cases in the city has risen to an average of 3,554 a day, an increase of 135% from the average two weeks ago. https://t.co/RFCod5Rzr6

For over a year, prominent women in India, including journalists, were reeled into a labyrinthine online scam, offering jobs and opportunities with Harvard University.
Who targeted them, and why, is a mystery. https://t.co/LJoJuG1qtM

When the story appeared on a local news site, the mayor’s spokesman denied it. Then the spokesman acknowledged it was true: Mayor Dave Bronson of Anchorage, Alaska, went to a city water treatment plant and shut off the fluoride in the city’s water system. https://t.co/3sk9Mv51w2

A former defense contractor from South Dakota was arrested on espionage-related charges after an undercover FBI operation in which he tried to provide classified national defense information to someone he believed to be a Russian agent, prosecutors said. https://t.co/OsMd0IY7rz

Harvard will not require SAT or ACT scores for admission through the next four years, extending a policy adopted during the coronavirus pandemic and adding fuel to the movement to permanently eliminate standardized test scores for admission. https://t.co/mdKaveBpNs
Super Typhoon Rai brought heavy rain and flooding to the southeastern part of the Philippines on Thursday, displacing thousands over a large area. https://t.co/HQErmPRTtJ https://t.co/NTxyOPl6NI

Harvard will not require SAT or ACT scores for admission through the next four years, extending a policy adopted during the coronavirus pandemic and adding fuel to the movement to permanently eliminate standardized test scores for admission. https://t.co/5r5IC1IpuI
Breaking News: A CDC panel recommended other Covid vaccines over Johnson & Johnson’s, citing the link to a rare but potentially fatal blood clotting disorder. https://t.co/nOXnjjEMnT
Breaking News: A federal judge overturned Purdue Pharma’s opioid settlement, ruling that the Sackler family could not receive protection from civil lawsuits. https://t.co/fAQnifIw69

Nearly all active-duty members of the Army and Navy — 98% — are vaccinated against Covid-19. The service members who still refuse shots will be dismissed, the military said. Thousands of troops requested religious exemptions, but none have been granted. https://t.co/icQ2yqcmLO

Breaking News: Women can get abortion pills by mail for pregnancies up to 10 weeks without seeing a doctor in person, the FDA ruled. The decision comes as the Supreme Court considers whether to roll back abortion rights or even overturn Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/Oc8jDUpHJl https://t.co/4ZY84CtzAH

Breaking News: Women can get abortion pills by mail for pregnancies up to 10 weeks without seeing a doctor in person, the FDA ruled. The decision comes as the Supreme Court considers whether to roll back abortion rights or even overturn Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/hutMjelRXU

Turkey's bakers say they can't afford to keep making bread because of price controls and rising inflation. And their customers can't afford to buy it anyway. https://t.co/Kw9IFREzPc https://t.co/23xF9ZyKpi

bell hooks, whose incisive, wide-ranging writing on gender and race helped push feminism beyond its white, middle-class worldview to include the voices of Black and working-class women, died on Wednesday. She was 69. https://t.co/9JNRSGKsoj https://t.co/nmjhFMJ1LP

While visiting Kentucky, President Biden praised the communities affected by the deadly tornadoes last weekend for how they’ve come together to handle the severe devastation. https://t.co/yu9heYfOwL https://t.co/SiNaDr50TL
Breaking News: Bruce Springsteen sold his music rights to Sony in a deal that may exceed $500 million in value, people briefed on the matter said. https://t.co/93GV2zDeO0
Keechant Sewell, the Nassau County chief of detectives, will become New York City’s first female police commissioner. https://t.co/mMCrZVJYEw

A group of people handcuffed a principal in northern Greece and took him to the police, suggesting that officers arrest him for enforcing Covid measures at a school.
Instead, the group was detained and now faces abduction charges. https://t.co/ys0eE5LWOv

Kroger, the U.S. supermarket operator, has eliminated paid Covid-19 leave for unvaccinated employees and will charge salaried employees who are enrolled in a company health care plan $50 a month if they remain unvaccinated, a spokeswoman said. https://t.co/7P6htEoEiY

Jordan Baize saw that the roof of his house in Kentucky had blown away during a tornado. But his Yamaha piano was still intact.
Under an overcast sky, Baize sat alone in his living room and started to play a song that had been stuck in his head for days. https://t.co/s7HZIl751f https://t.co/MR2q5FfhAF

Chicago's City Council approved a $2.9 million settlement on Wednesday for Anjanette Young, a medical social worker who was forced to stand naked in front of a dozen police officers who burst into her home to execute a search warrant in 2019. https://t.co/lGvOxtTSvs

Turkey's bakers say they can't afford to keep making bread because of price controls and rising inflation. And their customers can't afford to buy it anyway. https://t.co/eAkJChhEPf https://t.co/0lUzziU4Hj

bell hooks, whose incisive, wide-ranging writing on gender and race helped push feminism beyond its white, middle-class worldview to include the voices of Black and working-class women, died on Wednesday. She was 69. https://t.co/TUrsklsxAe https://t.co/Rhylcf0nwQ
Breaking News: Covid deaths in the U.S. surpassed 800,000, the highest known number of any country in the world. https://t.co/NZjAnVZSyo https://t.co/KBieNaUAwK

bell hooks, whose incisive, wide-ranging writing on gender and race helped push feminism beyond its white, middle-class worldview to include the voices of Black and working-class women, died on Wednesday. She was 69. https://t.co/uT7qoRZbV7 https://t.co/hW0CeOyfZ2

Steph Curry on Tuesday set a new NBA career record for 3-pointers, surpassing Ray Allen, who finished his career with 2,973 made 3-pointers and held the record for 10 years. https://t.co/YzNpTmqJrc https://t.co/PzDr2nEjt2

Malta became the first country in the E.U. to agree to legalize marijuana for recreational purposes, allowing people to carry up to seven grams of marijuana, grow up to four plants in their apartments and keep up to 50 grams of dried cannabis at home. https://t.co/JmncYxjsbp https://t.co/6DE8F1lpAn

A man returned to his Kentucky home to find that it had been largely demolished by a tornado, but that his piano was still intact. Listen as he plays the Christian worship song "There’s Something About That Name." https://t.co/qZrWIyetOY https://t.co/TTjQAP1EUJ
